jparsec.ephem.planets.imcce

Class Elp2000

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.ephem.planets.imcce.Elp2000

  • public class Elp2000
extends java.lang.Object
    This class implements the Lunar Solution ELP2000 from the IMCCE. The entire theory is applied.

    Reference frame is mean dynamical ecliptic and inertial equinox of J2000 epoch.

    References:

    1. ELP 2000-85: a semi-analytical lunar ephemeris adequate for historical times, Chapront-Touze M., Chapront J., Astron. & Astrophys. 190, 342 (1988).

    2. The Lunar Ephemeris ELP 2000, Chapront-Touze M., Chapront J., Astron. & Astrophys. 124, 50 (1983).

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    Ephem

    • Field Detail

      • MOON_SECULAR_ACCELERATION

        public static final double MOON_SECULAR_ACCELERATION
        Holds the value of the secular acceleration of the Moon. Currently equal to -25.858 arcsec/cent^2 (Chapront, Chapront-Touze and Francou, 2002).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • calc

        public static double[] calc(double JD,
            double prec)
        Computation of geocentric lunar coordinates from ELP 2000-82 and ELP2000-85 theories (M. Chapront-Touze and J. Chapront). Constants fitted to JPL's ephemerides DE200/LE200.

        Reference frame in mean dynamical ecliptic and inertial equinox of J2000 epoch.

        Files, series, constants and coordinate systems are described in the notice LUNAR SOLUTION ELP 2000-82B, available from the IMCCE.

        Parameters:
        JD - Julian Day in TDB.
        prec - Truncation level in arcseconds. Pass 0 to use the complete theory (slower).
        Returns:
        An array with the geocentric rectangular positions. Units are AU.

      • meanJ2000InertialToEquatorialFK5

        public static double[] meanJ2000InertialToEquatorialFK5(double[] position)
        Transform J2000 mean inertial coordinates into mean equatorial J2000. Specific to this theory (class) to compare positions with DE200.
        Parameters:
        position - Ecliptic coordinates (x, y, z) or (x, y, z, vx, vy, vz) refered to mean ecliptic and inertial equinox of J2000.
        Returns:
        Equatorial FK5 coordinates.

      • timeCorrectionForSecularAcceleration

        public static double timeCorrectionForSecularAcceleration(double jd)
        Corrects Julian day of calculations of ELP2000 theory for secular acceleration of the Moon. This method uses the current value of static variable MOON_SECULAR_ACCELERATION.

        Correction should be performed to standard dynamical time of calculations (Barycentric Dynamical Time), as obtained by using the corresponding methods. elp2000Ephemeris(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement) accepts any time scale, so it is possible to use the output Julian day of this method with any time scale, unless a very little error (well below the uncertainty in TT-UT correction) could exist if this correction is applied to LT or UT, before the correction to TDB which is performed in elp2000Ephemeris(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement).

        Correction for different years (using the default value) are as follows: 

         Year       Correction (seconds)
 -2000      -2796
 -1000      -1561
     0      -683
  1000      -163
  1955       0.000
  2000      -0.362
  3000      -195
        Parameters:
        jd - Julian day in TDB.
        Returns:
        Output (corrected) Julian day in TDB.

      • elp2000Ephemeris

        public static EphemElement elp2000Ephemeris(TimeElement time,
                            ObserverElement obs,
                            EphemerisElement eph)
                                     throws JPARSECException
        Calculate Moon position (center of mass), providing full data. This method uses ELP2000 theory from the IMCCE. Typical error is below 0.01 arcseconds when comparing to JPL DE200 Ephemeris. The position error in the original theory reached some arcseconds outside 20th century due to an uncertainty with Moon secular acceleration in JPL DE200 integration. So this theory was not accurate outside period 1900-2100, although it can be improved by correcting for Moon secular acceleration.

        The time correction for Moon secular acceleration is automatically done, which means that this implementation will match JPLDE405 up to the arcsecond level during several millenia. So the results cannot be compared directly with DE200 due to this time correction (well, only around year 1955). Another possible correction you may want to apply is from center of mass to geometric center by means of fromMoonBarycenterToGeometricCenter(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement, EphemElement).

        This method also uses Series96 theory for the position of the Earth between 1900 and 2100, and VSOP87A theory outside this interval. This could affect the heliocentric position and physical ephemeris.

        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph - Ephemeris object with the target and ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        Ephem object containing ephemeris data. Rise, set, transit times and maximum elevation fields are not computed in this method, use Ephem class for that.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • fromMoonBarycenterToGeometricCenter

        public static EphemElement fromMoonBarycenterToGeometricCenter(TimeElement time,
                                               ObserverElement observer,
                                               EphemerisElement eph,
                                               EphemElement ephem)
                                                        throws JPARSECException
        Corrects position of the Moon from its barycenter (center of mass) to its geometric center. This correction is -0.5 arcsec in ecliptic longitude, +0.25 arcsec in latitude, and +2 km in distance. See http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/LEcat5/ephemeris.html.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        observer - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        ephem - Ephem object.
        Returns:
        The new ephem object with corrected position.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing only.
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
